articles.headline: Casper Dreams of Being Bigger Than Mattresses
articles.snippet: The start-up wants to be the ‘Nike of sleep.’ It’s a slightly absurd concept — in a gigantic market.
articles.abstract: The start-up wants to be the ‘Nike of sleep.’ It’s a slightly absurd concept — in a gigantic market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neil Parikh hadn’t been getting a lot of rest, and it showed. It was deep into the afternoon, and Mr. Parikh, a founder of the direct-to-consumer mattress start-up Casper, was looking at the menu of a Midtown Manhattan coffee shop, debating whether it was too late for another cappuccino.

articles.headline: Boko Haram Is Back. With Better Drones.
articles.snippet: After a decade of devastating war with Boko Haram extremists, they are now better armed than ever and have more sophisticated drones than the demoralized Nigerian military.
articles.abstract: After a decade of devastating war with Boko Haram extremists, they are now better armed than ever and have more sophisticated drones than the demoralized Nigerian military.
articles.lead_paragraph: KONDUGA, Nigeria — Ten-year-old Abdul stood on a dirt road in a village tucked between millet fields and pulled up his shirt. A fresh scar stretched lengthwise down his stomach — the result of a suicide bombing by Boko Haram in June that sent shrapnel tearing through his belly.

articles.headline: The Concept Cars Gleam, but Executive Dread Clouds the Frankfurt Auto Show
articles.snippet: Trade war, technology shifts and a global downturn are putting “unprecedented” pressure on automakers. Sustainability is now about survival.
articles.abstract: Trade war, technology shifts and a global downturn are putting “unprecedented” pressure on automakers. Sustainability is now about survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Car executives are paid to be optimists, but behind the pomp and salesmanship at the Frankfurt International Motor Show this week lurked an unmistakable sense of angst.

articles.headline: Biden and Warren Avoid Direct Conflict — But for How Long?
articles.snippet: They have staked out diverging political paths, but have mostly refrained from attacking each other. Now a more combative phase of the race seems inevitable.
articles.abstract: They have staked out diverging political paths, but have mostly refrained from attacking each other. Now a more combative phase of the race seems inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: If Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Elizabeth Warren are headed for a showdown, neither of them appears in a hurry to get there.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: In Coal Country, the Mines Shut Down, the Women Went to Work and the World Quietly Changed
articles.snippet: From 2010 to 2017, Letcher County in Kentucky saw a greater shift in the gender balance of its labor force than almost any other county in the United States.
articles.abstract: From 2010 to 2017, Letcher County in Kentucky saw a greater shift in the gender balance of its labor force than almost any other county in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLEMING-NEON, Ky. — In the pre-dawn hours when all is dark and quiet, Amanda Lucas leaves her house and begins the long drive to her job at a hospital an hour away.

articles.headline: Trump Inspires California Lawmakers to Go on Offense
articles.snippet: California Democrats have been energized by a wave of anti-Trump sentiment to enact a sweeping liberal agenda that in almost every way offers a counternarrative to Trump administration policies.
articles.abstract: California Democrats have been energized by a wave of anti-Trump sentiment to enact a sweeping liberal agenda that in almost every way offers a counternarrative to Trump administration policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Sign up for our daily newsletter about news from California here.]
articles.byline: By Tim Arango, Thomas Fuller and Jose A. Del Real

articles.headline: Notre-Dame’s Toxic Fallout
articles.snippet: Flames engulfed 460 tons of lead when Notre-Dame’s roof and spire burned, scattering dangerous dust onto the streets and parks of Paris.
articles.abstract: Flames engulfed 460 tons of lead when Notre-Dame’s roof and spire burned, scattering dangerous dust onto the streets and parks of Paris.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flames engulfed 460 tons of lead when Notre-Dame’s roof and spire burned, scattering dangerous dust onto the streets and parks of Paris.
articles.byline: By Elian Peltier, James Glanz, Weiyi Cai and Jeremy White

articles.headline: Two Major Saudi Oil Installations Hit by Drone Strike, and U.S. Blames Iran
articles.snippet: Yemen’s Houthi rebels claimed responsibility. But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo accused Tehran and said the strikes were not launched from Yemen.
articles.abstract: Yemen’s Houthi rebels claimed responsibility. But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo accused Tehran and said the strikes were not launched from Yemen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drone attacks claimed by Yemen’s Houthi rebels struck two key oil installations inside Saudi Arabia on Saturday, damaging facilities that process the vast majority of the country’s crude output and raising the risk of a disruption in world oil supplies.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Palko Karasz and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Fearing ‘Spy Trains,’ Congress May Ban a Chinese Maker of Subway Cars
articles.snippet: A Chinese train maker, the world’s largest, has contracts in Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, but Congress may block it from securing any new contracts in the United States.
articles.abstract: A Chinese train maker, the world’s largest, has contracts in Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, but Congress may block it from securing any new contracts in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — America’s next fight with China is unfolding at a glistening new factory in Chicago, which stands empty except for the shells of two subway cars and space for future business that is unlikely to come.

articles.headline: ‘People Actively Hate Us’: Inside the Border Patrol’s Morale Crisis
articles.snippet: Overwhelmed by desperate migrants and criticized for mistreating the people in their care, many agents have grown defensive, insular and bitter.
articles.abstract: Overwhelmed by desperate migrants and criticized for mistreating the people in their care, many agents have grown defensive, insular and bitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: One Border Patrol agent in Tucson said he had been called a “sellout” and a “kid killer.” In El Paso, an agent said he and his colleagues in uniform had avoided eating lunch together except at certain “BP friendly” restaurants because “there’s always the possibility of them spitting in your food.” An agent in Arizona quit last year out of frustration. “Caging people for a nonviolent activity,” he said, “started to eat away at me.”
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Miriam Jordan, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Caitlin Dickerson and Kendrick Brinson

articles.headline: Saudi Oil Attack Photos Implicate Iran, U.S. Says; Trump Hints at Military Action
articles.snippet: The government released satellite images indicating, they said, that the strikes came from the direction of Iraq or Iran.
articles.abstract: The government released satellite images indicating, they said, that the strikes came from the direction of Iraq or Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration intensified its focus on Iran Sunday as the likely culprit behind attacks on important Saudi Arabian oil facilities over the weekend, with officials citing intelligence assessments to support the accusation and President Trump warning that he was prepared to take military action.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Farnaz Fassihi and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Kamala Harris Was Ready to Brawl From the Beginning
articles.snippet: In her first race, she defied her old boss, a fund-raising pledge — and the implication that she owed her career to her ex-boyfriend.
articles.abstract: In her first race, she defied her old boss, a fund-raising pledge — and the implication that she owed her career to her ex-boyfriend.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The rebuttal sounded something like a threat. That seemed to be Kamala Harris’s point.

articles.headline: G.M. Strike: 50,000 Union Workers Walk Out Over Wages and Idled Plants
articles.snippet: U.A.W. regional leaders in Detroit voted unanimously on Sunday morning to authorize the strike, the union’s first such walkout since 2007.
articles.abstract: U.A.W. regional leaders in Detroit voted unanimously on Sunday morning to authorize the strike, the union’s first such walkout since 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union went on strike at General Motors, sending nearly 50,000 members at factories across the Midwest and South to picket lines on Monday morning.

articles.headline: Real-Time Surveillance Will Test the British Tolerance for Cameras
articles.snippet: Facial recognition technology is drawing scrutiny in a country more accustomed to surveillance than any other Western democracy.
articles.abstract: Facial recognition technology is drawing scrutiny in a country more accustomed to surveillance than any other Western democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARDIFF, Wales — A few hours before a recent Wales-Ireland rugby match in Cardiff, amid throngs of fans dressed in team colors of red and green, and sidewalk merchants selling scarves and flags, police officers popped out of a white van.

articles.headline: Boeing Board to Call for Safety Changes After 737 Max Crashes
articles.snippet: A committee of the Boeing board reviewed how the company designs and builds planes. It identified areas for improvement and major issues facing the company.
articles.abstract: A committee of the Boeing board reviewed how the company designs and builds planes. It identified areas for improvement and major issues facing the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past five months, a small committee of Boeing’s board has been interviewing company employees, safety experts and executives at other industrial organizations in an attempt to understand how the aerospace giant could design and build safer airplanes.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Long Before ‘Netflix and Chill,’ He Was the Netflix C.E.O.
articles.snippet: A new memoir by Marc Randolph, the company’s first boss, provides a blast from the entertainment giant’s red-envelope past.
articles.abstract: A new memoir by Marc Randolph, the company’s first boss, provides a blast from the entertainment giant’s red-envelope past.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA CRUZ, Calif. — Long before binge-watching, the streaming wars and “Netflix and chill,” there were two guys barreling down Highway 17 — the California roadway that connects Santa Cruz to Silicon Valley — trying to come up with the next big thing.

articles.headline: Biden Has Deep Connection to Black Voters. Will It Translate Into Votes?
articles.snippet: The Democratic front-runner leads in the polls among African-Americans, and older black voters admire him. But it’s not “locked down,’’ said one party strategist.
articles.abstract: The Democratic front-runner leads in the polls among African-Americans, and older black voters admire him. But it’s not “locked down,’’ said one party strategist.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM — At the Democratic primary debate last week, Joseph R. Biden Jr. prompted some distress within the party with a rambling, discordant answer to a question about the legacy of slavery, a moment that highlighted his unsteady instincts, and mixed record, on matters of race.

articles.headline: A Challenge to Big Tech and Antitrust Thinking in a Surprising Place
articles.snippet: The University of Chicago has long been associated with the idea that antitrust decisions should be based on prices for consumers, not market dominance. That’s starting to change.
articles.abstract: The University of Chicago has long been associated with the idea that antitrust decisions should be based on prices for consumers, not market dominance. That’s starting to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: Convocation speeches are usually filled with inspiring life lessons or sage advice, but this year’s graduating class at the University of Chicago heard something else: a battle cry against tech monopolies from one of the school’s leading economists.

articles.headline: Israel Election Could Turn on Ugly Breakup of an Odd Couple
articles.snippet: For Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his former deputy Avigdor Liberman, Israel’s do-over election will cap a love-hate saga of three decades.
articles.abstract: For Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his former deputy Avigdor Liberman, Israel’s do-over election will cap a love-hate saga of three decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — They joined forces three decades ago, rising to power as a political odd couple like none Israelis had ever seen.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Trump Urges ‘Big’ Rate Cut as Fed Faces Challenges
articles.snippet: From short-term political and trade war concerns to a long-term lack of “firefighting capability” if the economy dives, things are not poised to get easier for Chair Jerome H. Powell.
articles.abstract: From short-term political and trade war concerns to a long-term lack of “firefighting capability” if the economy dives, things are not poised to get easier for Chair Jerome H. Powell.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is poised to cut interest rates for the second time this year on Wednesday as policymakers try to get ahead of economic risks emanating from a global slowdown, President Trump’s trade war and uncertainty about the road ahead.

articles.headline: Trump Says Iran Appears Responsible for Saudi Attack but That He Wants to Avoid War
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, who has been trying to draw the Iranians into talks, appeared to seek a de-escalation, saying “I know they want to make a deal.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, who has been trying to draw the Iranians into talks, appeared to seek a de-escalation, saying “I know they want to make a deal.”
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump said Monday that Iran appeared to have been responsible for the weekend attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities. But he also said he would “like to avoid” a military conflict with Tehran, emphasized his interest in diplomacy and played down the attack’s jolt to the global oil market.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña, David D. Kirkpatrick and Michael Crowley

articles.headline: Trump Cleared to Put More Tariffs on Europe in Airbus Case
articles.snippet: The World Trade Organization has made a final decision in a 15-year old dispute that now clears the way for the United States to impose tariffs on European products.
articles.abstract: The World Trade Organization has made a final decision in a 15-year old dispute that now clears the way for the United States to impose tariffs on European products.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The World Trade Organization will grant the United States permission to impose tariffs on the European Union as part of a prolonged scuffle over subsidies given to European plane maker Airbus, European officials said Monday, a move that is likely to exacerbate trade tensions across the Atlantic.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Milan Schreuer
